prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author of the situation described is in the wrong. The scenario involves a couple living together where the author pays all the bills because his girlfriend only works part-time. There was an incident where he asked her to pay for takeout, which she did with a negative attitude.

First, I need to analyze the situation from both sides. The author feels that because he's paying everything, his girlfriend should contribute, even if it's small. But he's using a single incident as a reason to make her pay more. The key points here are about fairness, communication, and expectations in a relationship.

The author might be in the wrong if he's being overly rigid. He's expecting her to take on financial responsibility based on one event. Maybe he didn't discuss splitting costs earlier, so it's unfair to suddenly make her pay more without prior conversation. On the other hand, if the girlfriend always relies on him and this is the first time she's asked to contribute, maybe the author is right to want her to start helping.

But the way he's approaching it—using a single incident as a trigger—might be unreasonable. Relationships require communication. If he never mentioned sharing expenses before, she might not have realized it was expected. Also, she works part-time, so her ability to contribute is limited. The author might be in a position where he's taking out his frustration from the takeout incident and overreacting by wanting her to take on more bills.

Another angle: financial expectations should be negotiated. If the author is paying all the bills, maybe that's their agreed-upon arrangement. The girlfriend might not have a say if he's the primary earner, but that doesn't mean she shouldn't contribute if she can. However, the author's reaction seems to be based on his own frustration rather than a fair assessment of her capacity.

In terms of the incident itself, asking her to pay for a $40 takeout isn't unreasonable if they split expenses. But the way she reacted might indicate underlying issues. Maybe she feels taken advantage of and is resentful. The author's frustration could stem from feeling unappreciated for covering all costs.

So, considering all this, the author might be in the wrong for not discussing financial responsibilities earlier and using a minor incident as a catalyst to change the arrangement without considering her perspective. He's making a significant change (making her pay some bills) based on a single event, which could be seen as unfair. Therefore, the answer might be A (Yes, the author is in the wrong).
